content:
Not all languages easily deal with utf-8 the way Python3 does. The unicode '±' (in the "Fake star" test & validator) will for instance appear as 2 chars in C.
Please replace all non-ASCII characters in the inputs by ASCII ones (e.g. '%').

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: because it is ment to teach the user something new and exciting while practicing conditions and nested for loops along with 2D arrays
tests and validators should be different

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting clash! It might be hard to do in less than 5 minutes, though. The special cases do need some extra time, but that's why they're there...
I feel like there are 1 too many of this exact type of program already in here no?
Could also be fun in the other game mode.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good idea, good Statements & easy too understand
The difficulty here is the speed ! perfect game mode !
Lot of upvote
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Not sure that the BLINDED and SEARCH rules are really interesting in that context (just two if to add).

Good idea!
In "2 Stars" are only 3 lines, not 4 and in Validator 3 is only 1 line not 2.
And normally, the x-coordinate is horizontal and not vertical. I think you changed x and y.

Thanks a lot for your comment. It's very appreciated :-)
I wanted to edit / resolve the issues that you correctly raised, but when I edit the project the correct number of lines are shown. I believe that the problem is with codingame.com which displays my problem on this review page by skipping empty lines.

Regarding x,y being horizontal,vertical you are right. I will correct these.

[EDIT: All updates done. You were right. I had to add empty spaces on the lines that weren't shown properly. Now it's fixed.]

Thanks for your comment. From the coding point of view I fully agree. I added these, because I see these exercises as well as educative games to expand the knowledge or promote interest in certain areas where software is applied.

Probably, but the point of this one is (on top of the codingame challenge) to additionally teach something interesting about spacecrafts in a very simplified way :-)
See one of my other comments below.

My tests and validators were initially different, but in the codingame chats, numerous people gave me the exact opposite advise to yours. Validators shall validate the same principle as the tests. For this exercise, the easiest to achieve this is to simply have them identical.

Thanks for your comment. I just updated the test & validator.
It's a pitty since I liked the ±  
;-)

Another remark. It does not really make sense that the lines aren't all the same size since the input is supposed to be a picture of the sky, as far as I understand (also it would help if you gave a common length at the beginning).

yes they should validate the same principle, but not use the same inputs.

like for example you can have a test for big numbers, then the validator should test that as well, but it should not use the same numbers.
